rsbNotes.title: Jer 46–51
rsbNotes.text: 46:1–51:64 This section of Jeremiah comprises a series of judgment oracles against the surrounding nations.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50–51
rsbNotes.text: 50:1–51:64 The prophecy against Babylon (cf. Is. 13:1–14:23; 21:1–9) is the climax of the book. The previous prophecies have served Jeremiah’s purpose of showing that Babylon would prevail over “all the nations” (27:7) for a period. Babylon has appeared up to this point as the instrument of God’s wrath. Finally, however (as in 25:17–26), “the word of the Lord” is uttered against Babylon itself, to show that its own time of judgment must come (25:11, 12). The Hebrew text of Jeremiah has placed the prophecy (actually delivered in 593 b.c.; see 51:59 note) at this point in the book so that the judgment on Babylon may occupy the climactic position. The relative length of the prophecy also shows how important Babylon is in the theology of the book.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:11
rsbNotes.text: 51:11 Medes. Babylon was conquered by an alliance of Medes and Persians (Introduction: Characteristics and Themes). See also Is. 13:17; 21:2.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:13
rsbNotes.text: 51:13 by many waters. Babylon was renowned for its irrigation channels, fed by the Euphrates River.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:14
rsbNotes.text: 51:14 sworn by himself. See Gen. 22:16 and note.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:20
rsbNotes.text: 51:20 You are my hammer. Apparently addressed to Babylon; vv. 20–23 should be taken together with vv. 24–26. Babylon was God’s “hammer” (50:23) against the nations, but later Babylon’s own sin would cause it to be judged.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:27
rsbNotes.text: 51:27 Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz. Assyrian administrative districts in Armenia.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:30
rsbNotes.text: 51:30 her dwellings are on fire. Babylon’s sacking of Judah (cf. 21:10) is being revenged by her Median conquerors.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:33
rsbNotes.text: 51:33 daughter of Babylon. This figure both personifies Babylon and alludes to its women, made vulnerable by defeat. See 50:42; Lam. 1:6 and note.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:36
rsbNotes.text: 51:36 plead . . . vengeance. See 50:15. The metaphors of revenge and courtroom judgment are mixed here.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:44
rsbNotes.text:
51:44 what he has swallowed. He “swallowed” the nations taken into exile and their treasures. Judah’s treasures were restored by Cyrus’s decree (Ezra 1:5–11).

wall of Babylon. An enormously wide double wall, further protected by an intervening moat.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:51
rsbNotes.text: 51:51 The exiles express their grief over the occupation of the temple by Nebuchadnezzar in 586 b.c., perhaps feeling that this defilement can never be cleansed.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:53
rsbNotes.text: 51:53 Though Babylon should mount up to heaven. Probably this is a reference to its lofty ziggurats, symbols of its religious pride (Gen. 11:4).
